{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Andrew Breitbart | image = Andrew Breitbart by Gage Skidmore 2.jpg | caption = Breitbart at [[Conservative Political Action Conference|CPAC]] in 2012 | birth_name = Andrew James Breitbart | birth_date = {{Birth date|1969|02|01}} | birth_place = [[Los Angeles]], California, U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|2012|03|01|1969|02|01}} | death_place = [[Westwood, Los Angeles, California]], U.S. | resting_place = [[Hillside Memorial Park Cemetery]] | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | occupation = Writer, columnist, journalist, publisher | alma_mater = [[Tulane University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]]) | spouse = {{marriage|Susannah Bean|1997|2012|end=his death}} | children = 4 | home_town = [[Brentwood, Los Angeles]], California, U.S. | website = {{URL|http://www.breitbart.com/}} }}
'''Andrew James Breitbart''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|b|r|aɪ|t|b|ɑr|t}}; February 1, 1969 – March 1, 2012) was an American [[conservatism in the United States|conservative]] publisher,<ref name="c-span"/> writer and commentator.
After helping in the early stages of ''[[The Huffington Post]]''<ref name="huff">{{cite web|url=http://news.cnet.com/Breitbart.com-has-Drudge-to-thank-for-its-success---page-2/2100-1025_3-5976096-2.html |title=Breitbart.com has Drudge to thank for its success |accessdate=July 29, 2009 |publisher=Cnet news |date=November 2005}}</ref> and the ''[[Drudge Report]]'',<ref>{{cite news|last=Ng|first=Christina|title=Publisher and Author Andrew Breitbart Dead|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/andrew-breitbart-publisher-author-dead/story?id=15824337#.UCsmqJZSTsY|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=August 15, 2012}}</ref> Breitbart created ''[[Breitbart (website)|Breitbart]]'', a news and right-wing opinion website, along with multiple other "BIG" sites - BIGHollywood, BIGGovernment, BIGJournalism. He played central roles in the [[Anthony Weiner sexting scandals|Anthony Weiner sexting scandal]], the [[firing of Shirley Sherrod]], and the [[ACORN 2009 undercover videos controversy]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.alternet.org/story/154463/what_really_killed_andrew_breitbart_the_likely_cause_of_death_the_mainstream_media_ignored|title=What Really Killed Andrew Breitbart? The Likely Cause of Death The Mainstream Media Ignored|last=Roshan|first=Maer|date=March 8, 2012|work=AlterNet|access-date=August 22, 2017|last2=Slayton|first2=Hunter R.}}</ref> Commenters such as [[Nick Gillespie]] and [[Conor Friedersdorf]] have credited Breitbart with changing how people wrote about politics by "show[ing] how the Internet could be used to route around information bottlenecks imposed by official spokesmen and legacy news outlets"<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/03/01/opinion/gillespie-breitbart/index.html|title=How Andrew Breitbart changed the news|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=March 2, 2012|first=Nick|last=Gillespie}}</ref> and "wield[ing] a rhetorical flamethrower in the culture wars" by using his own personal experiences and opinions as the basis for his media career.<ref name=Atlantic1>{{cite web | url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2012/03/andrew-breitbarts-legacy-credit-and-blame-where-its-due/253953/ | title=Andrew Breitbart's Legacy: Credit and Blame Where It's Due | publisher=Atlantic Media | work=Politics | date=March 8, 2012 | accessdate=January 13, 2015 | author=Friedersdorf, Connor}}</ref>
==Early life== Breitbart was born in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], on February 1, 1969.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/02/us/andrew-breitbart-conservative-blogger-dies-at-43.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|title=Andrew Breitbart, Conservative Blogger, Dies at 43|last1=Peters |first1=Jeremy W.|date=March 1, 2012|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=July 27, 2014}}</ref> He was the adopted son of Gerald and Arlene Breitbart, a restaurant owner and banker respectively, and grew up in the affluent neighborhood of [[Brentwood, Los Angeles]].<ref name="WAPO20120301" /> He was adopted at three weeks old and raised [[Jewish]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nndb.com/people/940/000203331/#FN1|title=Andrew Breitbart|publisher=NNDB|page=1|language=English|accessdate=August 29, 2017}}</ref> His biological parents had been [[Irish American]].<ref name="WAPO20120301">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/andrew-breitbart-built-internet-empire-by-combining-new-media-old-fashioned-pranks/2012/03/01/gIQA7vc9kR_story.html|title=Andrew Breitbart built Internet empire by combining new media, partisan slant|last=Farhi|first=Paul|date=March 1, 2012|publisher=The Washington Post|language=English|accessdate=August 16, 2017|location=United States}}</ref> He said that his birth certificate indicated his biological father was a folk singer. His adoptive mother had [[Conversion to Judaism|converted]] to Judaism when marrying his adoptive father.<ref name="family">{{cite news|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/politics/2010/03/what_is_andrew_breitbart_thinking.single.html |title=Big Breitbart: Andrew Breitbart is messing with you | author= Christopher Beam |journal =Slate Magazine |publisher= |accessdate=March 17, 2010 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100322191051/http://www.slate.com/id/2247593| archivedate= March 22, 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name="wsj">{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704471504574451703003340362?mod=WSJ_hpp_sections_opinion |title=The Weekend Interview With Andrew Breitbart: Taking On the 'Democrat-Media Complex' |work=The Wall Street Journal |accessdate=October 18, 2009 | first=James | last=Taranto | date=October 16, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091020224720/http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704471504574451703003340362.html?mod=WSJ_hpp_sections_opinion| archivedate= October 20, 2009 | deadurl= no}}</ref> Breitbart studied at [[Hebrew school]] and had a [[Bar Mitzvah]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Andrew Breitbart, Republican Jewish media mogul, is dead at 43|first=Jonah|last=Lowenfeld|date=March 1, 2012|work=[[The Jewish Journal of Greater Los Angeles|Jewish Journal]]|url=http://www.jewishjournal.com/thenon-prophet/item/andrew_breitbart_republican_jewish_media_mogul_is_dead_at_43_20120301}}</ref> Theologically he was an agnostic.<ref name="family"/>
Breitbart attended [[Brentwood School (Los Angeles)|Brentwood School]], one of the country's top private schools, but did not distinguish himself, saying: "My sense of humor saved me".<ref name="family"/> However, he discovered that he loved writing, publishing his first comedic piece in the school newspaper, the ''Brentwood Eagle'', analyzing the inequality in his high school's senior and junior parking lots: "One had Mercedes and BMWs, the other Sciroccos and GTIs.""<ref name="family"/> Breitbart remembers his upbringing as [[apolitical]], except in one instance: when the family's rabbi tried to defend [[Jesse Jackson]] against charges of antisemitism after his "[[Hymietown]]" comment, his parents left the synagogue in protest.<ref name="family"/>
Breitbart would remain "proudly and playfully Jewish" throughout his life, although not always religiously observant. He would sing Hebrew songs at work while also teasing his Orthodox Jewish colleagues for keeping a kosher diet.<ref name="jpost.com">[http://www.jpost.com/Jewish-World/Jewish-Features/Comment-Andrew-Breitbart-Israel-and-Judaism "Comment: Andrew Breitbart, Israel and Judaism"] By Benjamin Weinthal, ''Jerusalem Post'', April 3, 2012</ref> [[Joel Pollak]] wrote: "He carried his faith as he carried all his convictions: with a lighthearted touch but a deep commitment."<ref name="jpost.com"/> Breitbart later said of his profession: "I'm glad I've become a journalist because I'd like to fight on behalf of the Israeli people... And the Israeli people, I adore and I love."<ref name="jpost.com"/><ref>[http://www.jewishjournal.com/politics/article/andrew_breitbart_the_unabashedly_biased_journalist_20110613/ "Andrew Breitbart, the unabashedly 'biased journalist'”] by Jonah Lowenfeld, June 13, 2011, ''Jewish Journal''</ref>
While in high school, Breitbart worked as a [[pizza delivery]] driver; he sometimes delivered to celebrities such as [[Judge Reinhold]].<ref>''Righteous Indignation'', page 17</ref> He earned a [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] in [[American studies]] from [[Tulane University]] in 1991, graduating with "no sense of [his] future whatsoever."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2007/may/29/20070529-111812-9136r/print/|title='News addict' gets his fix|last=McCain|first=Robert Stacy|date=May 29, 2007|work=The Washington Times|accessdate=July 27, 2009}}</ref> His early jobs included a stint at [[cable television|cable]] channel [[E! Entertainment Television]], working for the company's [[blog|online magazine]], and some time in film production.<ref name="wsj"/>
Previously left-leaning in his politics, Breitbart changed his political views after experiencing "an [[epiphany (feeling)|epiphany]]" while watching the late 1991 [[Clarence Thomas Supreme Court nomination|confirmation hearings]] for Supreme Court justice [[Clarence Thomas]], due to what he considered unfounded attacks on the part of liberals based on former employee [[Anita Hill]]'s sexual harassment accusations.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.aim.org/podcast/take-aim-andrew-breitbart/|title= Take AIM: Andrew Breitbart }}</ref> Breitbart later described himself as "a [[Ronald Reagan|Reagan]] conservative" with [[Libertarianism|libertarian]] sympathies.<ref name="c-span"/>
Listening to radio hosts such as [[Rush Limbaugh]] helped Breitbart refine his political and philosophical positions, igniting an interest in learning that he had suppressed as a result of his distaste for the "nihilistic musings of dead [[critical theory|critical theorists]]"<ref name="Righteous Indignation, p. 36">Righteous Indignation, p. 36</ref> that had dominated his studies at Tulane. In this era, Breitbart also read [[Camille Paglia]]'s book ''[[Sexual Personae]]'' (1990), a massive survey of Western art, literature and culture from ancient Egypt to the 20th century, which, he wrote, "made me realize how little I really had learned in college."<ref name="Righteous Indignation, p. 36"/>
==Public life==
===Authorship, research, and reporting=== Breitbart has been lauded for his role in the "evolution of pioneering websites" including ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' and ''[[Drudge Report|The Drudge Report]]'', and more recently his "Big" sites. Journalists such as Nick Gillespie and Conor Friedersdorf have credited Breitbart with bringing new voices to debates about politics and culture. Breitbart told ''[[Reason (magazine)|Reason]]'' in 2004 that after feeling ignored by existing outlets, "We decided to go out and create our media." Described as "a series of do-it-yourself demonstration projects" and "conversation pits", the Breitbart websites have been both criticized and praised for their role in various political issues.<ref name=Atlantic1 /><ref name="Gillespie">{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/03/01/opinion/gillespie-breitbart/index.html|title=How Andrew Breitbart changed the news|date=March 2, 2012|work=[[CNN]]|accessdate=January 4, 2015|author=Gillespie, Nick}}</ref> Breitbart has been recognized for adopting an inclusive stance with regard to LGBT participation in the conservative movement. He has also been credited with helping to derail [[Barack Obama citizenship conspiracy theories|conspiracy theories about Barack Obama's citizenship]].<ref name=Atlantic1 />
In 1995, Breitbart saw ''The Drudge Report'' and was so impressed that he e-mailed [[Matt Drudge]]. Breitbart said, "I thought what he was doing was by far the coolest thing on the Internet. And I still do."<ref name="huff" /> Breitbart described himself as "Matt Drudge's [[bitch (insult)#In reference to men|bitch]]"<ref name="biyatch">{{cite web|url=http://www.reason.com/news/show/122048.html|title=Lists: What's Your Source for That? Where Andrew Breitbart gets his information.|accessdate=October 1, 2008|publisher=ReasonOnline.com| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080919111403/http://www.reason.com/news/show/122048.html| archivedate= September 19, 2008 | deadurl= no}}</ref> and selected and posted links to other news wire sources. Later, Drudge introduced him to a still-[[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] [[Arianna Huffington]]<ref name="wsj" /> and Breitbart subsequently assisted in the creation of ''The Huffington Post''.<ref>{{cite web|title=How Andrew Breitbart Helped Launch Huffington Post|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/buzzfeedpolitics/how-andrew-breitbart-helped-launch-huffington-post|publisher=Buzzfeed|accessdate=April 24, 2013}}</ref>
Breitbart wrote a weekly column for ''[[The Washington Times]]'', which also appeared at [[Real Clear Politics]]. Breitbart also co-wrote the book ''[[Hollywood, Interrupted|Hollywood, Interrupted: Insanity Chic in Babylon]]'' with [[Mark Ebner]], a book that is highly critical of U.S. [[celebrity culture]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-0471450510.html |title=Wiley: Hollywood, Interrupted: Insanity Chic in Babylon – The Case Against Celebrity – Andrew Breitbart, Mark Ebner |work=wiley.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090705051111/http://www.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-0471450510.html |archivedate=July 5, 2009 }}</ref> On January 19, 2011, the [[LGBT conservatism|conservative gay rights]] group [[GOProud]] announced Breitbart had joined its Advisory Council.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goproud.org/conservative-media-mogul-andrew-breitbart-to-join-goproud%E2%80%99s-advisory-council/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110803200215/http://www.goproud.org/conservative-media-mogul-andrew-breitbart-to-join-goproud%e2%80%99s-advisory-council/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=August 3, 2011 |title=Conservative Media Mogul Andrew Breitbart to Join GOProud's Advisory Council |publisher=Goproud.org |date=January 21, 2011 |accessdate=September 20, 2011 }}</ref>
In April 2011, Grand Central Publishing released Breitbart's book ''Righteous Indignation: Excuse Me While I Save the World'', in which he discussed his own political evolution and the part he took in the rise of [[new media]], most notably at the Drudge Report and ''The Huffington Post''.{{citation needed|date=February 2017}}
In June 2011, Breitbart's websites broke the story that congressman [[Anthony Weiner]] was [[Anthony Weiner sexting scandal|sending women revealing photographs of himself]].<ref>Daly, Corbett D. [http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20069298-503544.html "Conservative website posts private pictures of Anthony Weiner."] [[CBS News]]. June 6, 2011.</ref>
===Breitbart.com=== {{main|Breitbart News Network}} Breitbart launched his first website as a news site; it is often linked to by the ''[[Drudge Report]]'' and other websites. It has wire stories from the [[Associated Press]], [[Reuters]], [[Agence France-Presse]], [[Fox News]], [[PR Newswire]], and [[U.S. Newswire]], as well as direct links to a number of major international newspapers. Its political viewpoint as well as its audience runs to the [[right-wing|right]] within the U.S. political spectrum.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.journalism.org/interactives/media-polarization/outlet/breitbart/|title=Where Breitbart's Audience Fits on the Political Spectrum |date=October 21, 2014|work=Pew Research Center's Journalism Project}}</ref> In 2007, Breitbart launched a video blog, Breitbart.tv.<ref>[[Rob Owen (journalist)|Owen, Rob]]. [http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/07075/769897-96.stm The next wave: Ex-WTAE anchor Scott Baker changes channel to run Web news site], ''[[Post-Gazette]]''</ref>
In 2011, Breitbart and one of his editors [[Larry O'Connor (radio host)|Larry O'Connor]] were sued for [[defamation]] by [[Shirley Sherrod]], who had been [[Firing of Shirley Sherrod|fired]] after Breitbart posted a video of a speech given by Sherrod. The video had been selectively edited to suggest that she had purposely discriminated against a white farmer, while in reality the unedited video told the story of how she had helped that farmer.<ref>{{Cite news | last = Zeleny| first = Jeff|author2= Wheaton, Sarah| title = At Gathering, Ron Paul Is No. 1 for 2012| newspaper = [[The New York Times]]| pages = A21 | date = February 13, 2011| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/13/us/politics/13cpac.html?_r=1&emc=eta1 | accessdate =February 14, 2011}}</ref><ref name="Gerstein" /> In July 2015, it was reported that Sherrod and Breitbart's estate had reached a tentative settlement.<ref name="Gerstein">{{cite news|last1=Gerstein|first1=Josh|title=Breitbart, Sherrod near libel settlement|url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/under-the-radar/2015/07/breitbart-sherrod-near-libel-settlement-209824.html|accessdate=August 18, 2015|publisher=Politico|date=July 1, 2015}}</ref> It was reported October 1, 2016, that the lawsuit was settled.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://talkingpointsmemo.com/muckraker/sherrod-breitbart-lawsuit-settle |title= Ex-USDA Official Settles Her Lawsuit Over Breitbart Video That Got Her Fired |work= [[Talking Points Memo]] |author= Tierney Sneed |date= October 1, 2015 |accessdate= October 12, 2016}}</ref>
===Commentaries=== In 2009, Breitbart appeared as a commentator on ''[[Real Time with Bill Maher]]'' and ''[[Dennis Miller]]''.<ref>{{cite news|title=BREITBART: ‘My Real Time With Bill Maher’|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2009/mar/16/my-real-time-with-bill-maher/?page=all|accessdate=January 6, 2016|publisher=Washington Times|date=March 16, 2009}}</ref> In 2004, he was a guest commentator on [[Fox News Channel|Fox News Channel's]] morning show and frequently appeared as a guest panelist on [[Fox News]]'s late night program, ''[[Red Eye (TV series)|Red Eye w/ Greg Gutfeld]]''. Breitbart also appeared as a commentator in the 2004 documentary ''[[Michael Moore Hates America]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/articles/212271/michael-wilson-loves-america/andrew-leigh |title=National Review Online|publisher=nationalreview.com |accessdate=November 2, 2009 }}</ref>
On October 22, 2009, Breitbart appeared on the [[C-SPAN]] program ''[[Washington Journal]]''. He gave his opinions on the mainstream media, Hollywood, the [[Presidency of Barack Obama|Obama Administration]] and his personal political views, having heated debates with several callers.<ref name="c-span">[http://www.c-spanarchives.org/program/289587-8 Andrew Breitbart, Breitbart.com Publisher] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121002155759/http://www.c-spanarchives.org/program/289587-8 |date=October 2, 2012 }} [[C-SPAN]], October 22, 2009. Breitbart referred to the "Democrat-media complex" several times...</ref>
In the hours immediately following Senator [[Ted Kennedy]]'s death, Breitbart called Kennedy a "villain", a "duplicitous bastard", a "prick"<ref name="politico">{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0809/26475.html|title=Not all Kennedy critics hold fire|accessdate=August 26, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090827091650/http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0809/26475.html| archivedate= August 27, 2009| deadurl= no}}</ref> and "a special pile of human excrement," adding, "Sorry, he destroyed lives. And he knew it," referring to Kennedy's actions during the [[Chappaquiddick incident]], the [[Robert Bork Supreme Court nomination]], and the [[Clarence Thomas Supreme Court nomination]].<ref>"[http://www.pennlive.com/editorials/index.ssf/2009/08/compromise_what_pennsylvania_l.html Compromise: what Pennsylvania lawmakers could learn from Ted Kennedy]" (editorial), ''[[The Patriot-News]]'' (Pennsylvania), August 28, 2009. Retrieved September 24, 2009.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/article/278320 |title=Opinion: Ted Kennedy, the liberal adversary to the conservative movement |publisher=digitaljournal.com |accessdate=September 24, 2009 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091003110202/http://www.digitaljournal.com/article/278320| archivedate= October 3, 2009 | deadurl= no}}</ref>
In February 2010, Breitbart received the [[Reed Irvine]] [[Accuracy in Media]] Award during the [[Conservative Political Action Conference]] in Washington, D.C. During his acceptance speech, he responded directly to accusations by ''[[The New York Times]]'' reporter Kate Zernike that [[Jason Mattera]], a young conservative activist, had been using "racial tones" in his [[allusions]] to President [[Barack Obama]], and had spoken in a "[[Chris Rock]] voice". From the podium, Breitbart called Zernike "a despicable human being" for having made such allegations about what, according to him, was just Mattera's Brooklyn accent.<ref>Beam, Christopher, [http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/politics/2010/03/what_is_andrew_breitbart_thinking.html "'Media Is Everything. It's Everything.' Slate's 2010 profile of Andrew Breitbart"], ''Slate.com'', March 15, 2010.</ref> At the same conference, Breitbart was also filmed saying to journalist [[Max Blumenthal]] that he found him to be "a jerk" and "a despicable human being" over a blog entry in which Blumenthal accused Breitbart of employing a racist.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MIeByOeERpY |title=Max Blumenthal confronted by Andrew Breitbart and Larry O'Connor/Stage right at CPAC 10 |publisher=YouTube |date=February 20, 2010 |accessdate=March 1, 2012}}</ref> Blumenthal was referring to [[James O'Keefe]] over his having attended a [[Georgetown Law Center]] discussion on race featuring Kevin Martin, [[John Derbyshire]], and [[Jared Taylor]], the last of whom founded [[American Renaissance (magazine)|American Renaissance]], an online magazine widely considered white supremacist. Neither O'Keefe nor Breitbart endorsed Taylor's views.
In 2011, Breitbart said that "of course" [[Donald Trump]] was not a conservative, adding:
<blockquote>But this is a message to those candidates who are languishing at 2 percent and 3 percent within the Republican Party who are brand names in Washington, but the rest of the country don't know ... celebrity is everything in this country. And if these guys don't learn how to play the media the way that Barack Obama played the media last election cycle and the way that Donald Trump is playing the election cycle, we're going to probably get a celebrity candidate.<ref name="WP.Aug.7.16">{{cite news|last1=Weigel|first1=David|title=Five things to know about Breitbart, the new force in the Trump campaign|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2016/08/17/five-things-to-know-about-breitbart-the-new-force-in-the-trump-campaign/|accessdate=March 18, 2017|work=Washington Post|date=August 17, 2016}}</ref> </blockquote>
These comments resurfaced after the controversy of Donald Trump hiring [[Breitbart News]]' executive chairman [[Steve Bannon]] to be his [[White House Chief Strategist]].<ref name="WP.Aug.7.16" />
===Activism=== {{See also|Tea party movement#Reports of slurs at health care reform protests|l1=Tea Party movement}} Breitbart often appeared as a speaker at [[Tea Party movement]] events across the U.S. For example, Breitbart was a speaker at the first National Tea Party Convention at Gaylord Opryland Hotel in Nashville on February 6, 2010.<ref> [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_D2YLnaTr6w/ Breitbart Keynote Part 1 of 4, Nashville, February 2010]{{dead link|date=March 2012}} [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3N3os3js4B0/ Part 2]{{dead link|date=March 2012}} [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3t6XSeR5GEw/ Part 3]{{dead link|date=March 2012}} [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jJZmKGE6tdE/ Part 4]{{dead link|date=March 2012}}</ref> Breitbart later involved himself in a controversy over allegations of [[homophobia|homophobic]] and [[racism|racial]] slurs being used at a March 20, 2010, rally at the [[United States Capitol]] in Washington, D.C., by asserting that slurs were never used, and that "it was a set-up" by [[Nancy Pelosi]] and the Democratic Party. Breitbart offered to donate $100,000 to the [[United Negro College Fund]] "for any audio/video footage of the [[nigger|N-word]] being hurled," claiming that the several Congressmen made it up. Breitbart insisted Congressman [[John Lewis (Georgia politician)|John Lewis]] and several other witnesses were forced to lie, concluding that "Nancy Pelosi did a great disservice to a great civil rights icon by thrusting him out there to perform this mischievous task. His reputation is now on the line as a result of her desperation to take down the Tea Party movement."<ref name="AB-100402">{{cite web |url=http://bigjournalism.com/abreitbart/2010/04/02/barack-obamas-helter-skelter-insane-clown-posse-alinsky-planes-to-deconstruct-america/ |title=Barack Obama's Helter-Skelter, Insane Clown Posse, Alinsky Plans to 'Deconstruct' America |first=Andrew |last=Breitbart |publisher=Big Journalism |date=April 2, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302143429/http://bigjournalism.com/abreitbart/2010/04/02/barack-obamas-helter-skelter-insane-clown-posse-alinsky-planes-to-deconstruct-america/ |archivedate=March 2, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name="WPost Omb">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/04/09/AR2010040903716.html|title=Allegations of spitting and slurs at Capitol protest merit more reporting|date=April 11, 2010|work=Washington Post|accessdate=April 14, 2010| first=Andrew |last=Alexander}}</ref>
In February 2012, a YouTube video showed Breitbart yelling at Occupy D.C. protesters outside a Washington, D.C. hotel hosting a Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC). The video showed security escorting Breitbart back to the hotel while he told the protesters to "behave yourself", and alluding to reported assaults of women at Occupy encampments, he repeatedly yelled, "Stop raping people", and called the protestors "filthy, filthy, raping, murdering freaks!" David Carr said with the incident Breitbart had caused his last "viral storm on the Web."<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/15/business/media/the-life-and-death-of-andrew-breitbart.html?pagewanted=all |work=The New York Times |first=David |last=Carr |title=The Life and Death of Andrew Breitbart |date=April 13, 2012}}</ref><ref name=CPAC>Sources that describe the confrontation with Occupy protesters at CPAC 2012: * [http://www.theatlanticwire.com/politics/2012/02/web-talking-about-andrew-breitbarts-occupy-DC-freakout/48598/ The Web is Talking About Andrew Breitbart's Occupy D.C. ==Personal life== Breitbart was married to Susannah Bean, the daughter of actor [[Orson Bean]] and fashion designer Carolyn Maxwell, and had four children.<ref name="huff"/>{{Verify source|date=September 2018}}
==Death== On the night of March 1, 2012, Breitbart collapsed suddenly while walking in [[Brentwood, Los Angeles|Brentwood]]. He was rushed to [[Ronald Reagan UCLA Medical Center]], where he was pronounced dead just after midnight.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.autopsyfiles.org/reports/Celebs/breitbart,%20andrew_report.pdf |title=Andrew Breitbart autopsy report | publisher =Autopsyfile.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/andrew-breitbart-publisher-author-dead/story?id=15824337 |title=Publisher and Author Andrew Breitbart Dead |first=Christina |last=Ng |date=March 1, 2012}}</ref> He was 43 years old. An [[autopsy]] by the [[Los Angeles County Coroner's Office]] showed that he had [[hypertrophic cardiomyopathy]], with focal coronary atherosclerosis,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2012/05/commentator-and-editor-andrew-breitbart-died-of-heart-failure-and-hard-up-to-a-60-narrowing-of-a-major-artery-and-was-unde.html|title=Andrew Breitbart died of heart failure, narrowing of artery, coroner finds|first=Andrew|last=Blankstein|work=L.A. Times|publisher=L.A. Times|date=May 16, 2012}}</ref> and died of [[heart failure]].{{Citation needed|date=September 2018}} He was buried in the Jewish plot at the [[Hillside Memorial Park Cemetery]].{{Citation needed|date=September 2018}}
In remembrance, Republican presidential candidates [[Rick Santorum]], [[Mitt Romney]], and [[Newt Gingrich]] praised Breitbart.<ref name="media star">{{cite news|url=http://www.nwherald.com/2012/03/06/limbaugh-and-the-gop-the-media-stars-and-politics/agdmwrt/?page=3|title=Limbaugh and the GOP: The media stars and politics|author=Beth Fouhey|author2=Philip Elliott|work=Associated Press|date=March 6, 2012|accessdate=March 6, 2012}}</ref> Santorum called Breitbart's death "a huge loss" that strongly affected him.<ref name="media star"/><ref>{{cite video |date=March 1, 2012 |title=CBS News|url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/andrew-breitbart-death-shocks-santorum-100/2012/03/01/gIQAqm8qkR_video.html}}</ref> Romney praised Breitbart as a "fearless conservative," while Gingrich remembered him as "the most innovative pioneer in conservative activist social media in America".<ref name="media star" /> A special episode of ''[[Red Eye (TV series)|Red Eye w/ Greg Gutfeld]]'' aired the day after his death as the host and panelists paid their tributes and showed clips from his appearances on the show.<ref>{{cite video |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CLqEPe9emsU |title=Red Eye Remembers Andrew Breitbart |accessdate= September 3, 2016 }}</ref>

{{pp|small=yes}} '''Apraxia of speech''' ('''AOS''') is an acquired [[Motor speech disorders|oral motor speech disorder]] affecting an individual's ability to translate conscious speech plans into motor plans, which results in limited and difficult speech ability. By the definition of [[apraxia]], AOS affects [[Volition (psychology)|volitional]] (willful or purposeful) movement patterns, however AOS usually also affects [[automatic speech]].<ref name="West Hesketh 2005">{{cite journal|last1=West|first1=Carolyn |last2=Hesketh|first2=Anne| last3=Vail|first3=Andy| last4=Bowen|first4=Audrey|last5=West|first5=Carolyn|title=Interventions for apraxia of speech following stroke| year=2005| doi=10.1002/14651858.CD004298.pub2| pmid=16235357| issue=4| journal=Cochrane Database Syst Rev| pages=CD004298}}</ref>
Individuals with AOS have difficulty connecting speech messages from the brain to the mouth.<ref name="National Institutes of Health 2010">{{cite web|title=Apraxia of Speech|url=http://www.nidcd.nih.gov/health/voice/pages/apraxia.aspx|work=National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders|publisher=National Institutes of Health|accessdate=12 April 2012}}</ref> AOS is a loss of prior speech ability resulting from a brain injury such as a stroke or progressive illness.
[[Developmental verbal dyspraxia|Developmental verbal dyspraxia (DVD)]], also known as childhood apraxia of speech (CAS) and developmental apraxia of speech (DAS);<ref name="Morgan, 2009">{{cite journal |vauthors=Morgan AT, Vogel AP |title=A Cochrane review of treatment for childhood apraxia of speech |journal=Eur J Phys Rehabil Med |volume=45 |issue=1 |pages=103–10 |date=March 2009 |pmid=19156019 |doi= |url=http://www.minervamedica.it/en/journals/europa-medicophysica/article.php?cod=R33Y2009N01A0103 }}</ref><ref name="Vargha-Khadem 2005">{{cite journal |vauthors=Vargha-Khadem F, Gadian DG, Copp A, Mishkin M |title=FOXP2 and the neuroanatomy of speech and language |journal=Nat. Rev. Neurosci. |volume=6 |issue=2 |pages=131–8 |date=February 2005 |pmid=15685218 |doi=10.1038/nrn1605 |url=http://isites.harvard.edu/fs/docs/icb.topic1169974.files/FOXP2%20review%20Vargha%20Khadem.pdf}}</ref> is an inability to utilize [[motor planning]] to perform movements necessary for speech during a child's language learning process. Although the causes differ between AOS and DVD, the main characteristics and treatments are similar.<ref name="National Institutes of Health 2010"/><ref name="Maassen 2002">{{Cite journal | last1=Maassen| first1=B.| title=Issues contrasting adult acquired versus developmental apraxia of speech.| journal=Semin Speech Lang| volume=23| issue=4| pages=257–66 |date=Nov 2002| doi=10.1055/s-2002-35804| PMID=12461725}}</ref>
==Presentation== Apraxia of speech (AOS) is a neurogenic [[communication disorder]] affecting the motor programming system for speech production.<ref name="Ogar 2005">{{cite journal |vauthors=Ogar J, Slama H, Dronkers N, Amici S, Gorno-Tempini ML |title=Apraxia of speech: an overview |journal=Neurocase |volume=11 |issue=6 |pages=427–32 |date=December 2005 |pmid=16393756 |doi=10.1080/13554790500263529 |url=}}</ref><ref name="Knollman-Porter, 2008">{{cite journal |author=Knollman-Porter K |title=Acquired apraxia of speech: a review |journal=Top Stroke Rehabil |volume=15 |issue=5 |pages=484–93 |year=2008 |pmid=19008207 |doi=10.1310/tsr1505-484 |url=}}</ref> Individuals with AOS demonstrate difficulty in speech production, specifically with sequencing and forming sounds. The Levelt model describes the speech production process in the following three consecutive stages: conceptualization, formulation, and articulation. According to the Levelt model, apraxia of speech would fall into the articulation region. The individual does not suffer from a language deficiency, but has difficulty in the production of language in an audible manner. Notably, this difficulty is limited to vocal speech, and does not affect sign-language production. The individual knows exactly what they want to say, but there is a disruption in the part of the brain that sends the signal to the muscle for the specific movement.<ref name="Knollman-Porter, 2008"/> Individuals with acquired AOS demonstrate hallmark characteristics of [[Manner of articulation|articulation]] and [[Prosody (linguistics)|prosody]] (rhythm, stress or intonation) errors.<ref name="Ogar 2005"/><ref name="Knollman-Porter, 2008"/> Coexisting characteristics may include groping and effortful speech production with self-correction, difficulty initiating speech, abnormal stress, intonation and rhythm errors, and inconsistency with articulation.<ref name= Wertz/>
Wertz et al., (1984) describe the following five speech characteristics that an individual with apraxia of speech may exhibit:<ref name= Wertz>{{cite book |author1=Rosenbek, John C. |author2=Wertz, Robert T. |author3=LaPointe, Leonard L. |title=Apraxia of speech in adults: the disorder and its management |publisher=Grune & Stratton |location=New York |year=1984 |pages= |isbn=0-8089-1612-2 |oclc=13284954 |doi= |accessdate=}}</ref>
;Effortful trial and error with groping :Groping is when the mouth searches for the position needed to create a sound. When this trial and error process occurs, sounds may be held out longer, repeated or silently voiced. In some cases, an AOS sufferer may be able to produce certain sounds on their own, easily and unconsciously, but when prompted by another to produce the same sound the patient may grope with their lips, using volitional control (conscious awareness of the attempted speech movements), while struggling to produce the sound.<ref name="Knollman-Porter, 2008"/> ;Self correction of errors :Patients are aware of their speech errors and can attempt to correct themselves. This can involve distorted consonants, vowels, and sound substitutions. People with AOS often have a much greater understanding of speech than they are able to express. This receptive ability allows them to attempt self correction.<ref name="van der Merwe 2007">{{cite journal|last=van der Merwe|first=Anita|title=Self-Correction in Apraxia of Speech: The Effect of Treatment|journal=Aphasiology|date=June–August 2007|volume=21|issue=6-8|pages=658–669|doi=10.1080/02687030701192174}}</ref> ;Abnormal rhythm, stress and intonation :Sufferers of AOS present with prosodic errors which include irregular pitch, rate, and rhythm. This impaired prosody causes their speech to be: too slow or too fast and highly segmented (many pauses). An AOS speaker also stresses syllables incorrectly and in a monotone. As a result, the speech is often described as 'robotic'. When words are produced in a monotone with equal syllabic stress, a word such as 'tectonic' may sound like 'tec-ton-ic' as opposed to 'tec-TON-ic'. These patterns occur even though the speakers are aware of the prosodic patterns that should be used.<ref name=prosody>{{cite journal|last=Boutsen|first=F. R.|author2=Christman, S. S.|title=Prosody in apraxia of speech|journal=Seminars in Speech and Language|date=November 2002|volume=23|issue=4|pages=245–56|pmid=12461724|doi=10.1055/s-2002-35799}}</ref> ;Inconsistent articulation errors on repeated speech productions of the same utterance :When producing the same utterance in different instances, a person with AOS may have difficulty using and maintaining the same articulation that was previously used for that utterance. On some days, people with AOS may have more errors, or seem to "lose" the ability to produce certain sounds for an amount of time. Articulation also becomes more difficult when a word or phrase requires an articulation adjustment, in which the lips and tongue must move in order to shift between sounds. For example, the word "baby" needs less mouth adjustment than the word "dog" requires, since producing "dog" requires two tongue/lips movements to articulate.<ref name="Ogar 2005"/> ;Difficulty initiating utterances :Producing utterances becomes a difficult task in patients with AOS, which result in various speech errors. The errors in completing a speech movement gesture may increase as the length of the utterance increases. Since multisyllabic words are difficult, those with AOS use simple syllables and a limited range of consonants and vowels.<ref name="Ogar 2005"/><ref name="Knollman-Porter, 2008"/>
==Causes== Apraxia of speech can be caused by impairment to parts of the brain that control muscle movement and speech.<ref name="National Institutes of Health 2010"/><ref name="ASHA 2013">{{cite web | title=Apraxia of speech |publisher=American Speech-Language-Hearing Association |year=2013| url=http://www.asha.org/public/speech/disorders/ApraxiaAdults/}}</ref> However, identifying a particular region of the brain in which AOS always occurs has been controversial. Various patients with damage to left subcortical structures, regions of the insula, and Broca’s area have been diagnosed with AOS. Most commonly it is triggered by vascular lesions, but AOS can also arise due to tumors and trauma.<ref name="Ogar 2005"/>
===Acute apraxia of speech=== Stroke-associated AOS is the most common form of acquired AOS, making up about 60% of all reported acquired AOS cases. This is one of the several possible disorders that can result from a stroke, but only about 11% of stroke cases involve this disorder. Brain damage to the neural connections, and especially the neural synapses, during the stroke can lead to acquired AOS. Most cases of stroke-associated AOS are minor, but in the most severe cases, all linguistic motor function can be lost and must be relearned. Since most with this form of AOS are at least fifty years old, few fully recover to their previous level of ability to produce speech.
Other disorders and injuries of the brain that can lead to AOS include (traumatic) dementia, progressive neurological disorders, and traumatic brain injury.<ref name="ASHA 2013"/>
===Progressive apraxia of speech=== Recent research has established the existence of primary progressive apraxia of speech caused by [[Neuroanatomy|neuroanatomic]] motor [[atrophy]].<ref name="Josephs 2008">{{cite journal |vauthors=Josephs KA, Duffy JR |title=Apraxia of speech and nonfluent aphasia: a new clinical marker for corticobasal degeneration and progressive supranuclear palsy |journal=Current Opinion in Neurology |volume=21 |issue=6 |pages=688–92 |date=December 2008 |pmid=18989114 |doi=10.1097/WCO.0b013e3283168ddd |url=}}</ref><ref name="Josephs 2012">{{cite journal |vauthors=Josephs KA, Duffy JR, Strand EA |title=Characterizing a neurodegenerative syndrome: primary progressive apraxia of speech |journal=Brain |volume=135 |issue=Pt 5 |pages=1522–36 |date=May 2012 |pmid=22382356 |pmc=3338923 |doi=10.1093/brain/aws032 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> For a long time, this disorder was not distinguished from other [[motor speech disorders]] such as dysarthria and in particular [[primary progressive aphasia]]. Many studies have been done trying to identify areas in the brain in which this particular disorder occurs or at least to show that it occurs in different areas of the brain than other disorders.<ref name="Ricci 2008">{{cite journal |vauthors=Ricci M, Magarelli M, Todino V, Bianchini A, Calandriello E, Tramutoli R |title=Progressive apraxia of speech presenting as isolated disorder of speech articulation and prosody: a case report |journal=Neurocase |volume=14 |issue=2 |pages=162–8 |year=2008 |pmid=18569741 |doi=10.1080/13554790802060839 |url=}}</ref> One study observed 37 patients with [[Neurodegeneration|neurodegenerative]] speech disorders to determine whether or not it is distinguishable from other disorders, and if so where in the brain it can be found. Using [[Speech-language pathology|speech and language]], [[Neurology|neurological]], [[Neuropsychology|neuropsychological]] and [[neuroimaging]] testing, the researchers came to the conclusion that PAS does exist and that it correlates to superior lateral [[premotor cortex|premotor]] and supplementary motor atrophy.<ref name="Josephs 2012"/> However, because PAS is such a rare and recently discovered disorder, many studies do not have enough subjects to observe to make data entirely conclusive.
==Diagnosis== Apraxia of speech can be diagnosed by a [[Speech-Language Pathology|speech language pathologist]] (SLP) through specific exams that measure oral mechanisms of speech. The oral mechanisms exam involves tasks such as pursing lips, blowing, licking lips, elevating the tongue, and also involves an examination of the mouth. A complete exam also involves observation of the patient eating and talking. SLPs do not agree on a specific set of characteristics that make up the apraxia of speech diagnosis,{{Citation needed|date=May 2012}} so any of the characteristics from the section above could be used to form a diagnosis.<ref name="National Institutes of Health 2010"/> Patients may be asked to perform other daily tasks such as reading, writing, and conversing with others. In situations involving brain damage, an MRI brain scan also helps identify damaged areas of the brain.<ref name="National Institutes of Health 2010"/>
A [[differential diagnosis]] must be used in order to rule out other similar or alternative disorders. Although disorders such as expressive aphasia, conduction aphasia, and dysarthria involve similar symptoms as apraxia of speech, the disorders must be distinguished in order to correctly treat the patients.{{Citation needed|date=May 2012}} While AOS involves the motor planning or processing stage of speech, aphasic disorders can involve other language processes.<ref name="Croote 2002">{{cite journal|last=Croot|first=K.|title=Diagnosis of AOS: definition and criteria|journal=Seminars in Speech and Language|date=November 2002|volume=23|issue=4|pages=267–80|pmid=12461726 |doi=10.1055/s-2002-35800}}</ref>
According to Ziegler et al., this difficulty in diagnosis derives from the unknown causes and function of the disorder, making it hard to set definite parameters for AOS identification. Specifically, he explains that oral-facial apraxia, dysarthria, and aphasic phonological impairment are the three distinctly different disorders that cause individuals to display symptoms that are often similar to those of someone with AOS, and that these close relatives must be correctly ruled out by a Speech Language Pathologist before AOS can be given as a diagnosis. In this way, AOS is a diagnosis of exclusion, and is generally recognized when all other similar speech sound production disorders are eliminated.<ref>Ziegler, W., Aichert, I, & Staiger, A. (2012). American Speech-Language-Hearing Association supplement: Apraxia of speech: Concepts and controversies. Journal of Speech, Language, and Hearing Research, 55, 1485-1501.</ref>
===Possible co-morbid aphasias=== AOS and [[expressive aphasia]] (also known as Broca's aphasia) are commonly mistaken as the same disorder mainly because they often occur together in patients. Although both disorders present with symptoms such as a difficulty producing sounds due to damage in the language parts of the brain, they are not the same. The main difference between these disorders lies in the ability to comprehend spoken language; patients with apraxia are able to fully comprehend speech, while patients with aphasia are not always fully able to comprehend others' speech.<ref name="Choy 2010">{{cite journal |vauthors=Janet Choy J, Thompson CK |title=Binding in agrammatic aphasia: Processing to comprehension |journal=Aphasiology |volume=24 |issue=5 |pages=551–579 |date=May 2010 |pmid=20535243 |pmc=2882310 |doi=10.1080/02687030802634025 }}</ref>
[[Conduction aphasia]] is another speech disorder that is similar to, but not the same as, apraxia of speech. Although patients who suffer from conduction aphasia have full comprehension of speech, as do AOS sufferers, there are differences between the two disorders.<ref name="Robin 2008">{{cite journal |vauthors=Robin DA, Jacks A, Hageman C, Clark HM, Woodworth G |title=Visuomotor tracking abilities of speakers with apraxia of speech or conduction aphasia |journal=Brain Lang |volume=106 |issue=2 |pages=98–106 |date=August 2008 |pmid=18558428 |pmc=2579757 |doi=10.1016/j.bandl.2008.05.002}}</ref> Patients with conduction aphasia are typically able to speak fluently, but they do not have the ability to repeat what they hear.<ref name="Carlson 2010">{{cite book|last=Carlson|first=Neil R.|title=Psychology: the Science of Behavior|year=2010|publisher=Pearson Education|location=Canada|isbn=0205702864}}</ref>
Similarly, [[dysarthria]], another motor speech disorder, is characterized by difficulty articulating sounds. The difficulty in articulation does not occur due in planning the motor movement, as happens with AOS. Instead, [[dysarthria]] is caused by inability in or weakness of the muscles in the mouth, face, and respiratory system.<ref name=Dysarthria>{{cite web|title=Dysarthria|url=http://www.asha.org/public/speech/disorders/dysarthria.htm|publisher=The American Speech-Language-Hearing Association}}</ref>
==Management== In cases of acute AOS (stroke), spontaneous recovery may occur, in which previous speech abilities reappear on their own. All other cases of acquired AOS require a form of therapy; however the therapy varies with the individual needs of the patient. Typically, treatment involves one-on-one therapy with a speech language pathologist (SLP).<ref name="National Institutes of Health 2010"/> For severe forms of AOS, therapy may involve multiple sessions per week, which is reduced with speech improvement. Another main theme in AOS treatment is the use of repetition in order to achieve a large amount of target utterances, or desired speech usages.
There are various treatment techniques for AOS. One technique, called the Linguistic Approach, utilizes the rules for sounds and sequences. This approach focuses on the placement of the mouth in forming speech sounds. Another type of treatment is the Motor-Programming Approach, in which the motor movements necessary for speech are practiced. This technique utilizes a great amount of repetition in order to practice the sequences and transitions that are necessary in between production of sounds.
Research about the treatment of apraxia has revealed four main categories: articulatory-kinematic, rate/rhythm control, intersystemic facilitation/reorganization treatments, and alternative/augmentative communication.<ref name="Mauszycki 2011">{{Cite web|last1=Mauszycki |first1=Shannon C. |last2=Wambaugh |first2=Julie |title=Acquired Apraxia of Speech: A Treatment Overview |url=http://www.asha.org/Publications/leader/2011/110426/Acquired-Apraxia-of-Speech--A-Treatment-Overview/ |publisher=American Speech-Language-Hearing Association (ASHA) |year=2011 |accessdate=20 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130813183759/http://www.asha.org/Publications/leader/2011/110426/Acquired-Apraxia-of-Speech--A-Treatment-Overview/ |archivedate=13 August 2013 |df= }}</ref> *Articulatory-kinematic treatments almost always require verbal production in order to bring about improvement of speech. One common technique for this is modeling or repetition in order to establish the desired speech behavior. Articulatory-kinematic treatments are based on the importance of patients to improve spatial and temporal aspects of speech production. *Rate and rhythm control treatments exist to improve errors in patients’ timing of speech, a common characteristic of Apraxia. These techniques often include an external source of control like metronomic pacing, for example, in repeated speech productions. *Intersystemic reorganization/facilitation techniques often involve physical body or limb gestural approaches to improve speech. Gestures are usually combined with verbalization. It is thought that limb gestures may improve the organization of speech production. *Finally, alternative and augmentative communication approaches to treatment of apraxia are highly individualized for each patient. However, they often involve a "comprehensive communication system" that may include "speech, a communication book aid, a spelling system, a drawing system, a gestural system, technologies, and informed speech partners".
One specific treatment method is referred to as PROMPT. This acronym stands for Prompts for Restructuring Oral Muscular Phonetic Targets,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://promptinstitute.com/index.php?page%3Dwhat-is-prompt3 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-02-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222003537/http://promptinstitute.com/index.php?page=what-is-prompt3 |archivedate=2014-02-22 |df= }}</ref> and takes a hands on multidimensional approach at treating speech production disorders. PROMPT therapists integrate physical-sensory, cognitive-linguistic, and social-emotional aspects of motor performance. The main focus is developing language interaction through this tactile-kinetic approach by using touch cues to facilitate the articulatory movements associated with individual phonemes, and eventually words.
One study describes the use of electropalatography (EPG) to treat a patient with severe acquired apraxia of speech. EPG is a computer-based tool for assessment and treatment of speech motor issues. The program allows patients to see the placement of articulators during speech production thus aiding them in attempting to correct errors. Originally after two years of speech therapy, the patient exhibited speech motor and production problems including problems with phonation, articulation, and resonance. This study showed that EPG therapy gave the patient valuable visual feedback to clarify speech movements that had been difficult for the patient to complete when given only auditory feedback.<ref name="Howard Varley 1995">{{cite journal|last1=Howard| first1=Sara|last2=Varley| first2=Rosemary|title=III: EPG in Therapy Using electropalatography to treat severe acquired apraxia of speech|journal=International Journal of Language & Communication Disorders| volume=30|issue=2 |year=1995|pages=246–255|doi=10.3109/13682829509082535}}</ref>
While many studies are still exploring the various treatment methods, a few suggestions from ASHA for treating apraxia patients include the integration of objective treatment evidence, theoretical rationale, clinical knowledge and experience, and the needs and goals of the patient
==History and terminology== The term apraxia was first defined by [[Hugo Karl Liepmann]] in 1908 as the "inability to perform voluntary acts despite preserved muscle strength." In 1969, Frederic L. Darley coined the term "apraxia of speech", replacing Liepmann's original term "apraxia of the glosso-labio-pharyngeal structures." [[Paul Broca]] had also identified this speech disorder in 1861, which he referred to as "aphemia": a disorder involving difficulty of articulation despite having intact language skills and muscular function.<ref name="Ogar 2005"/>
The disorder is currently referred to as "apraxia of speech", but was also formerly termed "verbal dyspraxia". The term apraxia comes from the Greek root "praxis," meaning the performance of action or skilled movement.<ref name= Wertz/> Adding the prefix "a", meaning absence, or "dys", meaning abnormal or difficult, to the root "praxis", both function to imply speech difficulties related to movement.
==Research== Many researchers are investigating the characteristics of apraxia of speech and the most effective treatment methods. Below are a couple of the recent findings:
'''Sound Production Treatment:''' Articulatory-kinematic treatments have the strongest evidence of their use in treating Acquired Apraxia of Speech. These treatments use the facilitation of movement, positioning, timing, and articulators to improve speech production. Sound Production Treatment (SPT) is an articulatory-kinematic treatment that has received more research than many other methods. It combines modeling, repetition, minimal pair contrast, integral stimulation, articulatory placement cueing, and verbal feedback. It was developed to improve the articulation of targeted sounds in the mid-1990s. SPT shows consistent improvement of trained sounds in trained and untrained words. The best results occur with eight to ten exemplars of the targeted sound to promote generalization to untrained exemplars of trained sounds. In addition, maintenance effects are the strongest with 1–2 months post-treatment with sounds that reached high accuracy during treatment. Therefore, the termination of treatment should not be determined by performance criteria, and not by the number of sessions the client completes, in order to have the greatest long-term effects. While there are many parts of SPT that should receive further investigation, it can be expected that it will improve the production of targeted sounds for speakers with apraxia of Speech.<ref name="Wambaugh2010">{{cite journal|last1=Wambaugh |first1=J. |title=Sound Production Treatment for Acquired Apraxia of Speech |journal=Perspectives on Neurophysiology and Neurogenic Speech and Language Disorders |volume=20 |issue=3 |year=2010 |pages=67–72 |doi=10.1044/nnsld20.3.67 |url=http://www.ancds.org/documents/MembersOnly/SPT_Perspectives_Article.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203015843/http://www.ancds.org/documents/MembersOnly/SPT_Perspectives_Article.pdf |archivedate=2013-12-03 }}</ref>
'''Repeated Practice & Rate/Rhythm Control Treatments:''' Julie Wambaugh’s research focuses on clinically applicable treatments for acquired apraxia of speech. She recently published an article examining the effects of repeated practice and rate/rhythm control on sound production accuracy. Wambaugh and colleagues studied the effects of such treatment for 10 individuals with acquired apraxia of speech. The results indicate that repeated practice treatment results in significant improvements in articulation for most clients. In addition, rate/rhythm control helped some clients, but not others. Thus, incorporating repeated practice treatment into therapy would likely help individuals with AOS.<ref name="Wambaugh 2012">{{cite journal |vauthors=Wambaugh JL, Nessler C, Cameron R, Mauszycki SC |title=Acquired apraxia of speech: the effects of repeated practice and rate/rhythm control treatments on sound production accuracy |journal=Am J Speech Lang Pathol |volume=21 |issue=2 |pages=S5–27 |date=May 2012 |pmid=22230177 |doi=10.1044/1058-0360(2011/11-0102) |url=}}</ref>

'''Backbiting''', '''backstabbing''', or '''tale-bearing''' is [[slander]]ing someone in their absence — to bite them behind their back. Originally, backbiting referred to an unsporting attack from the rear in the blood sport of [[bearbaiting]].<ref>{{citation |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=a8SGwf0H7UwC&pg=PA166 |title=Why You Say It |author=Webb B. Garrison |chapter=To Backbite}}</ref>
In the [[Bahá'í Faith]], [[Christianity|Christian]], [[Islam|Islamic]] and [[Judaism|Jewish]] [[religious law|doctrine]], backbiting is considered a [[sin]]. The Bahá’í leaders condemned it as the worst of sins as it destroyed the 'life of the soul' and provoked [[divine wrath]].<ref>{{citation| url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=z7zdDFTzNr0C&pg=PA156 |title=An introduction to the Baha'i faith |author=Peter Smith}}</ref> [[Thomas Aquinas]] classified it as a [[mortal sin]], but did not consider it to be the gravest sin that one could commit against one's neighbour.<ref>{{citation |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=0gOm51etij0C&pg=PA158 |title=Summa Theologica |volume=2 |author=Thomas Aquinas; see "I answer that" in Article 3, http://www.newadvent.org/summa/3073.htm#article4}}</ref>In Islam, backbiting is known as Ghibat (غيبة) and Islam considers it to be a major sin and the [[Qur'an]] compares it to the abhorrent act of eating the flesh of one's dead brother.<ref>{{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=isDgI0-0Ip4C&pg=PA106 |author=Rafik Berjak |title=The Qur'an: an encyclopedia|chapter=Backbiting|publisher=[[Taylor & Francis]]|year=2006}}</ref>
In Judaism, backbiting is known as [[Lashon hara|''hotzaat shem ra'']] (spreading a bad name) and is considered a very severe sin.
In [[Buddhism]], backbiting goes against the ideal of [[right speech]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.accesstoinsight.org/lib/authors/various/wheel294.html|title=Right Livelihood: The Noble Eightfold Path in the Working Life|last=Jootla|first=Susan|year=1982|work=The Wheel|publisher=Buddhist Publication Society / Access to Insight|accessdate=7 June 2012}}</ref>
==Causes== Backbiting may occur as a form of release after a confrontation. By [[insulting]] the opposing person, the backbiter diminishes them and, by doing so, restores their own [[self-esteem]]. A bond may also be established with the confidant if they are receptive to the hostile comment. Such [[gossip]] is common in human society as people seek to divert [[blame]] and establish their place in the [[dominance hierarchy]].<ref name=BBC>{{citation |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/magazine/8649800.stm |title=Brown's 'bigot' remark: It's that sinking feeling |date= 29 April 2010 |publisher=BBC |author=Geoff Beattie}}</ref> But the backbiting may be perceived as a form of delinquent behaviour due to an [[inferiority complex]].<ref>{{citation |journal=The Educational review |year=1964 |title=Psychology of Backbiting |volume=70-71 |page=195 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Xu4UAAAAIAAJ}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Gossip]]
==References== {{reflist}} {{wiktionary|backbite}}
